sentences.sentence: I read with interest the opinion piece by Peter Moore ("Better land management is key to taming the flames", January 6).Oh, how I wish that he were right, but looking at the numbers I fear we might be kidding ourselves.

The vast 6.5 million hectares of bushland burnt is unprecedented in any one year, the ferocity now "catastrophic" in places, and we are only part way through our now clearly longer fire season.Due respect to Mr Moore for his experience in the forestry industry, but I can't accept that "better management" is all we will need to overcome our warming climate.
With multiple "hottest recorded days" in Australia in December, and most of the continent drier than ever, we really need to address the root cause of all this.
We have the natural resources and the know-how to reduce our (and our neighbours') carbon emissions.
It seems to me burning fossil fuels is effectively burning our home.

Time to price them out of the market.Thomas HuntOak Flats, NSWSlogans runningthe governmentMuch comment has already been made about Prime Minister Scott Morrison's decision to go on holiday as the bushfire crisis unfolded.The issue, however, is that the Prime Minister is a marketer.
Once the campaign has been market-tested successfully, all marketers want to do is dream up the next campaign.

Hence the complete absence of federal leadership during a time of crisis, followed by a slick online video setting out how much is being done.The federal government got elected on the basis of three successful slogans - we will stop the boats, return to surplus, and bring electricity prices down.
In the complete absence of any logical policy framework, the only basis for decision-making in the light of new circumstances is consistency with these slogans.
(Stay on-message!)

Hence the government saw the repeal of the medevac legislation as a triumph, just as the bushfires were getting started.The key question is whether the marketer, now that he's running the shop, will acknowledge that he's got some operational responsibilities.

Peter GayenHazelwood Park, SACheck arson withtough sentencingThe toll of the summer's bushfires is rising and everyone from Scott Morrison to the greenies is being held responsible.While we are so desperately seeking someone to blame, an unpalatable truth remains on the sidelines - most bushfires are deliberately lit and the offenders are receiving inadequate sentences.The purpose of any sentence is to punish and rehabilitate, to deter criminals from reoffending and to protect the community.The Sentencing Council of Victoria reported last April that the number of people sentenced for arson from 2013 to 2018 was between 20 and 30 annually.

While the majority received a sentence of imprisonment, more than 85 per cent received a sentence of less than four years, with the average being 2½ years.Unacceptable behaviour only responds to appropriate discipline and consequences.

Surely it is about time that we imposed more severe sentences if we are to have any chance of deterring and rehabilitating these offenders and, more importantly, any hope of protecting the community?Rosalind LemmeyNoosaville, QldDigital services taxhas Brexit-like feelAustralia can go it alone with digital services taxes or join a wider part-global community ("Global tech tax best for Australia", January 6).The arguments are analogous with the Brexit situation.

Sooner or later the community will fall apart even if agreement is initially reached.By far the best option for Australia is to follow the lead of France, Britain, Italy, Austria, Turkey and other countries and go it alone.
Countries will be far better placed if they determine their own digital services tax rates that bear relationship to domestic tax rates.
Becoming part of a wide part-global taxing community will significantly diminish national sovereignty.The proposals for an international tax are ludicrously complex.

Additionally, the US is arguing the international tax should be optional.The main criterion for benchmark turnover taxes applied to Australian generated revenues of multinational corporations is to be fair and reasonable.
The best tax is a simple tax.

The system is easy to operate with turnover taxes collected upfront with GST.Graeme TroyWagstaffe, NSWHave we forgottenthe Gillard era?According the editorial ("Morrison should follow business on climate risk", January 7), the federal government should be listening to business groups on climate policy because business has been calling for a stable climate policy to drive investment.Come again?
Are these the same business groups that welcomed the repeal of the Gillard government's carbon price?
Let's not re-write history.

Business groups have a lot to answer for in Australia's shameful climate policy debacle.Andrea BuntingBrunswick, VicAnother take onnegative gearingThe political difficulties in addressing negative gearing and the capital gains discount remain seemingly insurmountable in the face of the ALP's failed attempts to do so at the last election.The ALP's mistake was to put forward a radical solution that was itself seen to be unfair.I have an alternative solution, which as far as I am aware has not been suggested before, to discourage speculation in the housing market.The present tax laws make it clear that an expense incurred in gaining assessable income is an allowable deduction.This is sensible and reasonable and a principle that should be retained.But let us discourage speculation by attacking it from the capital gains angle.My suggestion is that if, when an investor comes to realise his investment, the total amount of expenses incurred (and claimed as such) by him over the life of his investment exceeds the total income received during the same period, the taxpayer's cost base for CGT purposes should be reduced by the amount of that excess, thereby increasing his overall capital gain.A genuine investor, for example, one whose expenses initially exceed his income but who later reduces his debt or receives higher income so that in later years his investment turns from tax negative to tax positive, would be unaffected by this change in the law.David TaylorDouble Bay, NSW
